element.attribution-notes: Letter written by a Loukios (otherwise unknown) to Evagrius.
element.description: Included in this corpus because of its importance for contextualizing the Antirrhetikos, and because it has no CPG number.
element.label: nocpg01

element.description: Fourteen chapters.
element.label: nocpg02
element.textual-notes: Part of the pseudo-supplement to the Kephalaia Gnostika (BL Add. 14578, fols. 148v-149; Frankenberg ed. 460-68 [nos. 44-57]; also in Armenian). See also Skemmata (CPG 2433).

element.description: Twelve brief chapters culled from Doctrina Patrum §34. See Casiday, Evagrius Ponticus 183–184
element.label: nocpg03

element.description: Paris BN 2748, ff. 153–83v, published by Muyldermans. Of the 69 chapters, 53 are drawn from other chapters in the corpus. See Casiday, Evagrius Ponticus 172–173
element.label: nocpg04

element.description: Fragment preserved on Acts 10:11-12; edited in Cramer’s Catenæ græcorum patrum in novum testamentum, 3:177
element.label: nocpg05

element.description: First of a trilogy (along with Gnostikos and the Kephalaia gnostika, below) considered fundamental to Evagrius's thought. This treatise contains 100 chapters discussing the preliminary disciplines of the ascetic life, especially the passions.
element.incipit: Ἐπειδή μοι πρώην δεδήλωκας ἀπὸ τοῦ ἁγίου ὄρους ἐν τῇ Σκίτει καθεζομένῳ

element.description: Second part of the trilogy (see Praktikos), comprising 50 chapters. In this treatise gnostika, mental or spiritual formation, is discussed.
element.incipit: Πρακτικοὶ λόγους νοήσουσι πρακτικούς, γνωστικοὶ δὲ ὄψονται γνωστικά
element.title-el: Γνωστικὸς ἢ Πρὸς τὸν καταξιωθέντα γνώσεως

element.description: Third part of the trilogy (see Praktikos), comprising 540 chapters (90 chapters in six "centuries") discussing the highest levels of contemplation. This text is frequently considered to be behind the condemnations of Origen in 553.
element.incipit: Τῷ πρώτῳ ἀγαθῷ οὐδέν ἐστιν ἐναντίον, διότι κατ' οὐσίαν ἐστίν· ἐναντίον δὲ οὐδὲν τῇ οὐσίᾳ.
element.textual-notes: Because of how little survives in Greek, the Syriac translations are key, especially the so-called unexpurgated version (frequently called S2). It is unclear whether the sole Arabic MS (Coptic Patriarchate MS Theol. 152, fol. 147r–177v) is taken from the Greek or Syriac and if the latter, which version.

element.incipit: Ὁ Χριστὸς ᾗ μέν ἑστι Χριστὸς, ἔχει τὴν γνῶσιν τὴν οὐσιώδη
element.textual-notes: Sixty-five sentences culled by textual scholars in three sections: 39 taken from the Gnostic Chapters, 23 from On Thoughts, and 3 unparalleled (and so termed a supplement). The Greek, Armenian, and Syriac versions of this text differ in sequence, number, and selection. This text, according to Mar Babai (569-628), who wrote an extensive commentary on the Kephalaia gnostica, was a supplement to the 540 chapters of the 600 promised in the Kephalaia gnostica (Mar Babai's version of Reflections contained only 60 chapters). Gennadius's reference to 'sententiae obscurae' may attest to an early Latin translation of this text. See also 14 Chapters (nocpg02).

element.description: Lists of Scriptures that are effective in combatting the eight passions. The text is organized according to the eight passions with scriptures listed according to their biblical order.
element.incipit: Της λογικης φυσεως της υπο τον ουρανον το μεν πολεμειται το δε βοηθει τω πολεμουμενω τε και καρτερως επεγειρει κατ αυτου την μαχην και συνισται

element.description: A set of 137 chapters on the monastic life, written in distychs, in imitation of the Proverbs, directed probably to a monastic community in Jerusalem associated with Melania and Rufinus. Evagrius discusses matters foundational to the coenobitic monastic life, so the material resembles, in some ways, a rule.
element.incipit: Κληρονόμοι θεοῦ ἀκούσατε λόγων θεοῦ, συγκληρονόμοι δὲ Χριστοῦ δέξασθε ῥήσεις Χριστοῦ
element.textual-notes: Often associated with CPG 2436 under the designation 'The Mirrors.'
element.title-el: Πρὸς τοὺς ἐν κοινοβίοις ἢ συνοδίαις μοναχούς

element.description: 56 sentences of spiritual instruction addressed to a virgin (unnamed, but probably an associate of Melania and Rufinus), written in distychs, in imitation of the Proverbs. Evagrius discusses matters foundational to the coenobitic monastic life for women, so the material resembles, in some ways, a rule.
element.incipit: Ἀγάπα τὸν κύριον καὶ ἀγαπήσει σε, καὶ δούλευε αὐτῷ καὶ φωτιεῖ τὴν καρδίαν σου.
element.textual-notes: Often associated with CPG 2435 under the designation 'The Mirrors.'

element.description: A collection of 62 letters (see also CPG 2438, 2439; cover letters to other treatises, e.g., CPG 2430, 2434) of various lengths, all providing spiritual counsel to various figures such as Rufinus, St. Melania the Elder, St. Gregory Nazianzus, Bp. John of Jerusalem.

Evagrius's last (?) and longest extant letter. It deals extensively with Christology and the ministry of letter writing, as well as the apokatastasis (the restoration of all things at the end of time). Although one Syriac MS describes the recipient as Melania the Elder (attested in Jerome's 'ad eam'?), this is generally regarded as incorrect. See the arguments of Bunge (in his German translation), who considers Rufinus to be more likely.
element.incipit: το λεγομενον οτι ο δηχθεις υπ' εχιδνης

element.attribution-notes: The letter was included in the first printed editions of Basil's letters, despite the mixed attributions in manuscripts. In 1923 Bousset and Melcher in separate publications argued that it should be attributed to Evagrius. Authorship is all but certain.
element.description: Evagrius's first extant letter, dealing with Trinitarian doctrine and his flight from Pontus, among other things. It was written around 380, and reflects Evagrius's tutelage with Gregory of Nazianzus during the latter's stormy tenure in Constantinople.
element.incipit: Πολλάκις ἐθαύμασα τί ποτε πεπόνθατε
element.title-la: Sermo sive dogmatica epistula de sanctissima trinitate

element.description: Twin treatises on prayer and other monastic disciplines.
element.textual-notes: Some MSS include a 3rd treatise, unedited, incipit Memento semper promissionum tuarum. See CPG, s.v.

element.description: Treatise in eleven sections describing the basic disciplines for living the monastic life. At the forefront is a concern to cultivate hesychia—stillness or tranquility—and to advance the fight against evil powers. Advice centers on diet, dress, work, companionship, dwelling, visitation habits, wealth, possessions, commerce, fasting, vigils, and prayer. Evagrius enjoins the constant contemplation of death, of Hades and its torments, of the day of judgment, of the punishments in store for the wicked, and of rewards for the righteous, all as a weapon against harmful thoughts.
element.incipit: Ἐν τῷ Ἱερεμίᾳ εἴρηται τὸ, Καὶ σὺ μὴ λάβῃς σεαυτῷ γυναῖκα ἐν τῷ τόπῳ τούτῳ
element.title-el: Ὑπωτύπωσις ἢ Τῶν κατὰ μοναχῶν πραγμάτων τὰ αἰτία, καὶ ἡ καθ᾿ ἡσυχίαν τούτων παράθεσις
element.title-en: Hypotyposis or Principles of the Monastic Life

element.description: Collection of 33 chapters relating physical and spiritual ailments to each other. The last 17 appear to be drawn from a commentary on Proverbs he wrote (see CPG 2456).
element.incipit: Ἴκτερος, ἔστιν ἕξις χειρίστη ψυχῆς λογικῆς, καθ' ἣν ἐσφαλμένως Θεόν τε καὶ τὴν τῶν γεγονότων θεωρίαν ὁρᾷ.

element.description: Three works, CPG 2443 through 2445, are very similar, comprising 24, 24, and 26 proverbs, respectively. These brief texts resemble other ancient Christian collections of proverbs, many of which originate with non-Christian authors, but adapted to a Christian context.
element.incipit: Ἀρχὴ σωτηρίας ἡ ἑαυτοῦ κατάγνωσις.

element.description: See CPG 2443.
element.incipit: Ἄτοπόν ἐστιν τὸ διώκοντα τὰς τιμὰς φεύγειν τοὺς πόνους, δι' ὧν αἱ τιμαί.

element.description: See CPG 2443.
element.incipit: Ἀρχὴ ἀγάπης ὑπόληψις δόξης.

element.textual-notes: Only the first sentence has been edited.

element.description: Lengthy treatise (thirty-two sections by Sinkewicz's new numbering) introducing the ascetic life. The wide array of topics concern primarily praktika, but gnostika is certainly not neglected. Subjects include voluntary exile, virtue, humility, battle with the thoughts (not enumerated here), cultivation of godly thoughts, work, poverty, spiritual direction, gossip, jealousy, demons, prayer, and communal life. The preface indicates that this treatise was also a letter sent to a monk Eulogios, the recipient of CPG 2448.
element.incipit: Οἱ τον οὐράνιον χῶρον νεμόμενοι τοῖς πόνοις, οὐ τῇ γαστρὶ, οὐδὲ τῇ μερίμνῃ τῶν φθαρτῶν ἀτενίζουσι·
element.textual-notes: The Greek text has been greatly enhanced by Sinkewicz's edition, which publishes for the first time the longer rescension of Lavra Γ ʹ 93.
element.title-en: Treatise to the Monk Eulogius or To Eulogius on the Confession of Thoughts and Counsel in Their Regard

element.description: Address to the monk Eulogios (the recipient of CPG 2447). This brief treatise concisely describes the evil thoughts and the virtues opposed to them. Each of nine chapters epitomizes the characteristics of a vice, then that of its antithetical virtue. The sequence is: (1) gluttony versus abstinence, (2) fornication versus chastity, (3) avarice versus freedom from possessions, (4) sadness versus joy, (5) anger versus patience, (6) acedia versus perseverance, (7) vainglory versus freedom from vainglory, (8) jealousy vesus freedom from jealousy, (9) pride versus humility. This departs from the traditional eight vices, because Evagrius inserts jealousy (recurs in CPG 2447).
element.incipit: Ἀναγκαῖον ἡγοῦμαι καὶ τὰς ἀντιζύγους τῶν ἀρετῶν κακίας δι' ἐπιτόμου ὑποτάξαι τῇ σῇ φιλοπονίᾳ·
element.title-el: Περὶ τὰς ἀντιζήλους τῶν ἀρετῶν κακίας
element.title-en: On the Vices Opposed to the Virtues
element.title-la: De vitiis quae opposita sunt virtutibus

element.attribution-notes: Attributed tentatively to Nilus of Ancyra

element.description: Relatively lengthy treatise of 43 sections. Evagrius analyzes closely the tactics of demons and the counterattacks available to the ascetic. He explains relationships between the various evil thoughts, and provides a glimpse into the epistemic, anthropological, and cosmological notions that undergird his advice on spiritual warfare.
element.incipit: Τῶν ἀντικειμένων δαιμόνων τῇ πρακτικῇ, πρῶτοι κατὰ τὸν πόλεμον συνίστανται
element.textual-notes: Only the first half (about twenty-three chapters) are reproduced in the Philokalia published by Nikodomeos the Hagiorite; they roughly correspond to the Guillaumont edition.

element.description: A brief but rich treatise of eight chapters, one for each evil thought (in this order): gluttony, fornication, avarice, anger, sadness, acedia, vainglory, pride. Each chapter contains mostly brief aphorisms, frequently set in pairs, occasionally punctuated by longer discursive paragraphs. Evagrius's advice, on how to combat the evil thoughts, is filled with metaphorical imagery, intended, as so many of his works, to be read slowly and contemplated.
element.incipit: Ἀρχὴ καρποφορίας, ἄνθος, καὶ ἀρχὴ πρακτικῆς, ἐγκράτεια·
element.title-el: Περὶ τῶν οκτῶ πνευμάτων τῆς πονηρίας

element.attribution-notes: Shown in the 1930s to be by Evagrius, despite its attribution in the Greek manuscript tradition to St. Nilus.
element.description: One of Evagrius's most widely read treatises, consisting of a prologue and 153 chapters on prayer.
element.incipit: Πυρέττοντά με τῷ φλογμῷ τῶν παθῶν, συνήθως ἀνεκτήσω
element.title-el: Περὶ προσευχῆς ἢ Λόγος εἰς ρνγʹ κεφαλαῖα διειλημμένος

element.description: First chapter is taken from the Hypotyposis (CPG 2441).

A text of 58 chapters in two sections (of 16 and 42 chapters, after longer and shorter recensions are collated). The chapters are generally proverbial admonitions to monks regarding the life of virtue and combat with the evil thoughts.
element.incipit: Ἀκρασίαν βρωμάτων περικόπτει νηστεία, ἀκολασίαν δὲ πορνείας περιαιρεῖ ἐγκράτεια μετὰ προσευχῆς.

element.attribution-notes: Derive from catenae of scriptural commentary (incorrectly attributing them to Origen or Athanasius) and unedited MSS.
element.description: Evagrius's comments on the Psalms. These scholia originate apparently from an extensive, now lost, commentary on the Psalms.
element.incipit: βουλὴ ἀσεβῶν ἐστι λογισμὸς ἐμπαθὴς αἰσθητοῖς πράγμασι τὸν νοῦν προσδεσμῶν.
Παροιμία ἐστὶν λόγος δι' αἰσθητῶν πραγμάτων σημαίνων πράγματα νοητά.

element.title-en: Commentary on the Parables and the Proverbs
element.title-la: Expositio in Parabolas et in Proverbia Salomonis

element.textual-notes: Collections of sayings found in the later (esp. 9th-10th c.) compilations of patristic biblical exegesis. Remains to be edited.
element.title-el: Σχόλια εἰς τὸν Γένεσιν, Ἀρίθμους, καὶ Βασιλείους
element.title-en: Scholia on Genesis, Numbers, and Kings
element.title-la: Scholia in Genesim, Numeros et Reges

element.textual-notes: Collections of sayings found in the later (esp. 9th-10th c.) compilations of patristic biblical exegesis. Remains to be edited.
Collections of sayings found in the later (esp. 9th-10th c.) compilations of patristic biblical exegesis. Remains to be edited.
element.title-el: Σχόλια εἰς τὸν ᾎσμα τῶν ἀσμάτων
element.title-en: Scholia on the Song of Songs

element.textual-notes: Collections of sayings found in the later (esp. 9th-10th c.) compilations of patristic biblical exegesis. Remains to be edited.

element.incipit: Ἐκκλησία ἐστὶν ψυχῶν καθαρῶν γνῶσις ἀληθὴς αἰώνων καὶ κόσμων καὶ τῆς ἐν αὐτοῖς κρίσεως καὶ προνοίας.
element.textual-notes: Collections of sayings found in the later (esp. 9th-10th c.) compilations of patristic biblical exegesis. Remains to be edited.
Collections of sayings found in the later (esp. 9th-10th c.) compilations of patristic biblical exegesis. Remains to be edited.

element.description: 7 stories and sayings attributed to Evagrius from the alphabetical collection.

element.title-en: On the Imitation of the Song of Songs

element.description: Identical to one of the thirty memre of the Syriac Book of Steps (Liber graduum; memre 14 in Patrologia Syriaca edition).

element.attribution-notes: Each of the three recensions of this text is attributed to a different author: John Lycopolis, Epiphanius, Macarius (or Evagrius)
element.title-en: Admonition on the Marks of Serenity
Dialogue of a Master with his Student
The Defense of One Led by God
element.title-la: De tutelis eius qui a deo ducitur

element.textual-notes: Gennadius's reference to "sententiae obscurae" may attest to an early Latin translation of this text.

element.title-en: Chapters of Counsel and Instructive Sermon

element.label: 2482a
element.title-en: Letter to a Bishop of Antioch Concerning Patience
element.title-la: Epistula ad episcopum Antiochenum de patientia

element.attribution-notes: Not directly Evagrius, but a collection of his sayings compiled by his students (cf. Apophthegmata, CPG 2462).
element.incipit: Ἄτεχνος κυβερνήτης ἕτοιμος ναυαγία καὶ ἀνεπιστήμων ἡγούμενος ἀπόλεια μαθητών.
